Judge

Memorandum Opinion No.Â  2009-MO-013
Heard March 3, 2009 â€“ Filed March 9, 2009Â

      John E.
        Cheatham, of Lexington, for Petitioner.

PER CURIAM:Â  We granted writ of certiorari to review the court of appealsâ€™
  unpublished order dismissing the appeal of Appellant.Â  Having fully considered
  the record and applicable law, we affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and
  the following authorities: USAA
    Property & Casualty Insurance Co. v. Clegg, 377 S.C. 643, 652, 661 S.E.2d 791, 796 (2008) (holding
  this Court grants deference to the circuit courtâ€™s credibility determination
  when evaluating the timeliness of a motion for reconsideration, as the circuit
  court is in a better position to evaluate credibility and assign comparative
  weight to testimony); Green v. Green, 320 S.C. 347, 351, 465 S.E.2d 130,
  132 (Ct. App. 1995) (stating that the proper standard of review when
determining if a motion was timely served by mail is abuse of discretion).[1]
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER, BEATTY, KITTREDGE, JJ., and Acting Justice James E. Moore,
  concur.


[1]Â 
  This Court carefully reviewed the underlying proceeding in connection with
  Appellantâ€™s Rule 59, SCRCP, motion.Â  Our decision to affirm the dismissal
  results in no prejudice to Appellant for Appellantâ€™s post-trial motion was
  meritless and certainly would have been denied.

PER CURIAM: 
  The State seeks a writ of certiorari to review the order of the circuit court
  granting respondentâ€™s application for post-conviction relief (PCR).Â  We grant
  the Stateâ€™s petition, dispense with further briefing, and reverse.Â  
The PCR judge relied on S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  17-27-45(C) (2003) and Coats v. State, 352 S.C. 500, 575 S.E.2d 557
  (2003) in finding respondentâ€™s PCR application was not time-barred.Â  However,
  we find respondentâ€™s PCR application was time-barred under Â§ 17-27-45(C).
Because
